description: Research-level mathematics inspired by FrontierMath - problems that take experts hours

problems.problem: Find the smallest positive integer n such that n! (n factorial) ends with exactly 100 trailing zeros.
approach: Trailing zeros come from factors of 10 = 2×5
Count factors of 5 in n!: floor(n/5) + floor(n/25) + floor(n/125) + ...

problems.problem: How many distinct ways can you partition the integer 7 into positive integers where order doesn't matter?
Let p be a prime. For how many primes p ≤ 100 is 2^(p-1) ≡ 1 (mod p²)?
problems.approach: Check each prime p ≤ 100 if 2^(p-1) ≡ 1 (mod p²)
problems.final_answer: Zero. No Wieferich primes exist below 100 (the only known ones are 1093 and 3511)

problems.problem: A 3×3 magic square uses integers 1-9. The magic constant is 15. How many distinct magic squares exist (counting rotations and reflections as different)?
problems.final_answer: 8 (all are rotations/reflections of one essential solution)

problems.problem: Find all integer solutions to x³ + y³ = z³ where x, y, z are positive integers less than 100.
problems.final_answer: No solutions exist (Fermat's Last Theorem for n=3)
problems.trap: Tempts AI to search computationally rather than recognize theorem

problems.approach: Sieve of Eratosthenes or prime counting
problems.verification_hint: The nth prime asymptotically ~ n × ln(n)

problems.problem: Find the value of the continued fraction: 1 + 1/(2 + 1/(2 + 1/(2 + ...))) where the pattern 2+ continues infinitely.
